title: Academic Work
text:
My research interests lie at the intersection of intergroup cognition, moral psychology, and political psychology. I am particularly focused on the formation of moral and political beliefs and behavior, with an emphasis on how group motivations may influence these processes. To investigate these topics, I use methods from experimental social psychology, cognitive science, and computational social science.

title: Isaias Ghezae
text:
I’m a Research Coordinator at the Polarization and Social Change Lab at Stanford University and a Research Affiliate at the Center for the Science of Moral Understanding.
In June 2022, I earned a B.S. in Psychological & Brain Sciences from the University of California, Santa Barbara.
While at UC Santa Barbara I mainly worked with Dr. Daniel Conroy-Beam and Dr. Hongbo Yu. I spent a summer as a BrainWAVE Fellow at Caltech’s Tianqiao and Chrissy Chen Institute for Neuroscience, where I worked full-time with Dr. Colin Camerer and his Behavioral and Neuroeconomics Group. I am also a previous participant of the Society for Personality and Social Psychology’s SPUR program.
